title: Abortion protest extremists: No pro-choice rights even in rape, incest
description: The few protesters who showed up agreed 'it's not fair to be raped' but insisted 'it is never medically necessary to have an abortion.' That's false.

I went to an anti-abortion event and found confusing messages, no crowds and the will to fight harder

That's false. Connie SchultzUSA TODAYAs a columnist, it is not uncommon to receive event invitations from people who hold values they know to be in direct opposition to your own. An attempt to goad, perhaps, as if to say: Attend if you dare.  In my experience, this outreach comes most frequently from groups committed to denying women access to legal and safe abortions. Sometimes, their preprinted postcards fill USPS bins deposited on the front of porch of our home with handwritten postscripts from self-declared Christians who hope for our eternal damnation in the bowels of hell. In their world, God is a bully. This past week, I heard from Mark Harrington, founder of Created Equal, an anti-abortion group headquartered in Columbus, Ohio. This is a small but vocal group of extremists who oppose abortion even in cases of rape or incest, or when the woman’s life is threatened. For context, as The New York Times reported in 2019, an NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll found that "strong majorities supported the rape and incest exception, including more than 30 percent of those who describe themselves as pro-life."Help Terms of Service Subscription Terms & Conditions Privacy Policy Our Ethical Principles Responsible Disclosure Site Map Your Privacy Choices© 2024 USA TODAY, a division of Gannett Satellite Information Network, LLC.
